item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Will China Close Its Doors?
item.description: A law to control foreign NGOs could shut down international exchanges.
item.dc:creator: IRA BELKIN and JEROME COHEN

item.title: Fighting in Ukraine Eases, but Abuses Continue on Both Sides, U.N. Says
item.description: Over 6,400 have been killed and 16,000 injured since fighting broke out between Ukraine and pro-Russian separatists in 2014.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Remains of soldiers killed in fighting between Ukraine and pro-Russian separatists being removed from the airport in Donetsk, Ukraine, in May.

item.title: Beijing Tries to Clear Its Notoriously Dirty Air — of Cigarette Smoke
item.description: The city’s authorities say a new ban on smoking in enclosed public spaces will guide people to quit, but there are widespread doubts about how strictly the law will be enforced.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: Smoking near the entrance to a children's hospital in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: Bangladesh Police Charge 41 With Murder Over Rana Plaza Collapse
item.description: More than 1,100 people were killed in the 2013 collapse of the building, which housed several clothing factories, in what is the garment industry’s worst disaster.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: The collapsed Rana Plaza building near Dhaka, Bangladesh, in 2013.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chubby Blue Cat Hints at Thaw in Ties Between China and Japan
item.description: A Doraemon movie is the first Japanese film to be shown in Chinese theaters since Tokyo nationalized a group of disputed islands in the East China Sea in 2012.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Willy Wo-Lap Lam on ‘Chinese Politics in the Era of Xi Jinping’
item.description: Willy Wo-Lap Lam, a 62-year-old professor at Chinese University of Hong Kong. is the author of five books analyzing China’s top leaders since Zhao Ziyang.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, who has veered away from the “first among equals” approach in favor of the “big boss” model, according to the China scholar Willy Wo-Lap Lam.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Standoff Over Rescued Dogs in Northeast China
item.description: Dog traders, animal rights activists and the authorities have been negotiating for more than a week over control of nearly 500 dogs rescued from a truck stopped on a highway in northeast China.
item.dc:creator: CHERIE CHAN
item.media:credit: Jiandu Gonggong Shipin Weisheng Anquan Zhiyuanzhe Tuandui
item.media:description: The nearly 500 dogs were crammed into small cages on a truck before being rescued.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Shaking Up the Status Quo in Nepal
item.description: A new volunteerism, community spirit and social consciousness have emerged from disaster.
item.dc:creator: BLAIR GLENCORSE and SUJEEV SHAKYA

item.title: Malaysia Airlines Chief Says Carrier Is Technically Bankrupt
item.description: The newly appointed chief executive of the loss-making airline also announced plans for a restructuring that will cut the company’s workforce by a third.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Solar Impulse Plane to Land in Japan Due to Bad Weather
item.description: A solar plane attempting to fly around the world without a drop of fuel plans to make an unscheduled stop Monday night in Nagoya, Japan, because of bad weather.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: The Solar Impulse 2 plane before taking off from Nanjing, China, on Sunday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Trial of Chinese Lawmaker Features Accusations of Prostitution
item.description: Liang Yaohui became a multimillionaire before he was targeted in a crackdown on vice and was charged in a prostitution scandal.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and MIA LI

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Destroys Confiscated Ivory and Vows to End Trade
item.description: Beijing hopes to reduce the poaching of elephants, which is driven by Chinese consumers’ demand for ivory.
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO and CHERIE CHAN
item.media:description: A Chinese police officer watching over ivory products before their destruction Friday in Beijing.

item.title: Key Parts of Patriot Act Expire Temporarily as Senate Moves Toward Limits on Spying
item.description: The government’s authority to sweep up bulk phone data in the hunt for terrorists expired temporarily at 12:01 a.m. Monday, but the Senate indicated that legislation to curtail the program is likely to pass this week.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER STEINHAUER and JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and the majority leader, grudgingly approved debate on the House bill.

item.title: Prices Are Down, but Saudis Keep Oil Flowing
item.description: The change is upending the traditional market dynamics that have influenced the direction of oil prices for decades.
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS and STANLEY REED
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction in the King Abdullah Financial District in Riyadh. Oil production has surged in Saudi Arabia, which is trying to keep up with its own growing demand.

item.title: For Swapped Taliban Prisoners From Guantánamo Bay, Few Doors to Exit Qatar
item.description: As the United States pressed Qatar for a six-month travel ban for the former Guantánamo detainees exchanged for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, no countries appeared eager to let them in.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: U.S. Citizens Held in Yemen by Houthis
item.description: At least four Americans were believed to be in custody in the capital, Sana, which is under rebel control.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: ISIS Gains Syrian Area Near Border
item.description: The Islamic State advanced against rival insurgents on Sunday and captured a town and two villages that are close to a crossing with Turkey.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Families of 1972 Munich Victims Find New Hope for Remembrance
item.description: A memorial for the 1972 attack will be built in Munich this year, and Olympic officials have shown support for recognition at the Rio Games.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Ankie Spitzer, the widow of a victim in the Munich Olympics attack, spoke at a tribute on the 40th anniversary in 2012.

item.title: Diriyah Journal: Saudis Turn Birthplace of Wahhabism Ideology Into Tourist Spot
item.description: Saudi officials hope a massive project to rebuild Diriyah, featuring parks, restaurants, and museums about traditional Saudi life, will link citizens to their past.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors at the Diriyah complex, on the outskirts of Riyadh, the Saudi capital. The site will feature parks, restaurants, and a series of museums.

item.title: Retro Report: The Unrealized Horrors of Population Explosion
item.description: In 1968, a book by a Stanford biologist predicted doom for the planet in coming decades. Whatever became of the population bomb?
item.dc:creator: CLYDE HABERMAN
